Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738–39 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: These post‑judgment developments constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the minor child’s best interests, necessitating modification of the parenting time schedule as to midweek overnights and associated transitions.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The case does apply the G.L. c. 208, § 28 standard that a modification requires a ‘material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties’ and that the modification must be necessary in the child’s best interests, but it does so in the context of a motion to modify *custody* and a split‑custody arrangement of twins—not modification of parenting time/midweek overnights or transitions. The opinion does not discuss post‑judgment developments involving scheduling or parenting time logistics, nor does it hold that such developments, as a category, constitute a material and substantial change requiring modification. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about modifying parenting time based on post‑judgment developments relating to midweek overnights and transitions.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ … In allowing the wife’s complaint for modification, the judge cited as a material and substantial change in circumstances, the wife’s ‘great success in overcoming her alcohol and drug dependence.’”

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.proposition: These post‑judgment developments constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the minor child’s best interests, necessitating modification of the parenting time schedule as to midweek overnights and associated transitions.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.support_reasoning: The case concerns modification of alimony and child support based on an alleged material change in the payor’s financial circumstances, not modification of parenting time or custody based on post-judgment developments affecting a child’s best interests. The opinion articulates the general standard that a party seeking modification must show a material change of circumstances, but it is limited to financial support obligations and does not address parenting schedules, midweek overnights, or transition issues. Using this case as authority for modification of parenting time based on such developments misapplies its holding.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). In this case, the judge held that Chester did not prove the requisite change of circumstances.”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have held that when post‑judgment circumstances affecting a child’s daily life and stability significantly change, and the existing order is no longer consistent with the child’s best interests, a Probate and Family Court may and should modify the order.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt deals with statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and the limits on a judge’s authority to order a custodial mother to relocate back to Massachusetts after she has lawfully moved. It does not discuss standards for post‑judgment modification of existing custody or visitation orders based on changed circumstances or best interests; instead, it vacates an initial judgment that was entered under an incorrect legal framework. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition regarding modification of orders upon post‑judgment changes in circumstances affecting a child’s stability.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: “The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. … As a matter of law, it should make no difference to a parent’s freedom to relocate that another party subsequently files to establish parental rights. See G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), (b).”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have held that when post‑judgment circumstances affecting a child’s daily life and stability significantly change, and the existing order is no longer consistent with the child’s best interests, a Probate and Family Court may and should modify the order.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The case discusses the best‑interests standard in an initial custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and criticizes an interim temporary order, but it does not involve or decide a post‑judgment modification based on changed circumstances. The court explicitly declines to apply or analyze the ‘substantial change in circumstances’ standard under G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and instead treats the matter as a straight custody determination, not a modification. Thus, it does not stand for a rule about when a Probate and Family Court may or should modify an existing order due to post‑judgment changes affecting stability.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have held that when post‑judgment circumstances affecting a child’s daily life and stability significantly change, and the existing order is no longer consistent with the child’s best interests, a Probate and Family Court may and should modify the order.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case is a removal/relocation decision under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a general post‑judgment modification case about changed circumstances affecting a child’s daily life and stability. The SJC focuses on defining the ‘cause shown’/best‑interests standard for removal where there is joint physical custody, and then affirms the trial judge’s denial of removal. Although the opinion briefly quotes ALI Principles referring to relocation as a ‘substantial change in circumstances,’ it does not hold or discuss that Massachusetts courts may or should modify prior orders whenever post‑judgment circumstances significantly change; the modification doctrine is not its subject or holding.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
“The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:
‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgment of divorce]…
‘(4)…the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests…’”}```

Boucher v. Boucher, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 35.raw_text: Boucher v. Boucher, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 35 (2016)
Boucher v. Boucher, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 35.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have held that when post‑judgment circumstances affecting a child’s daily life and stability significantly change, and the existing order is no longer consistent with the child’s best interests, a Probate and Family Court may and should modify the order.
Boucher v. Boucher, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 35.case_name: McLaughlin v. American States Insurance Co.
Boucher v. Boucher, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 35.support_reasoning: This case is a Massachusetts Appeals Court decision about unfair insurance settlement practices under G.L. c. 93A and c. 176D in the context of property damage caused by a well, not about child custody, parenting plans, or modification of Probate and Family Court orders. The opinion does not discuss post‑judgment changes in circumstances affecting a child’s life or the standards for modifying family‑law orders. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition concerning child-related order modifications.
Boucher v. Boucher, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 35.relevant_excerpt: We likewise discern no error in the trial judge’s conclusion that ASIC failed to conduct a reasonable investigation of the McLaughlins’ claim, as required by G. L. c. 176D, § 3(9)(d). As our summary of the judge’s extensive factual findings makes plain, ASIC failed to subject Harrington’s initial denial of responsibility to serious scrutiny and failed to take even the most basic steps toward obtaining an independent or neutral assessment of his potential fault.

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have held that when post‑judgment circumstances affecting a child’s daily life and stability significantly change, and the existing order is no longer consistent with the child’s best interests, a Probate and Family Court may and should modify the order.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The case concerns a custodial parent’s request to remove children from Massachusetts and the proper application of the Yannas ‘real advantage’ test under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not the general standard for modifying post‑judgment custody or parenting orders based on changed circumstances. The only discussion of modification standards is a narrow point correcting the trial judge’s view of what counts as a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ under G.L. c. 208, § 28, specifically holding that remarriage after divorce can be such a change. The opinion does not state that whenever post‑judgment circumstances affecting a child’s daily life and stability change significantly, the Probate and Family Court may and should modify an existing order; it focuses instead on removal and on recognizing remarriage as a qualifying change, so the broader proposition is overstated if cited to this case alone.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28… ‘[U]pon a complaint after a divorce … the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ Changed circumstances are those that occur subsequent to the judgment of divorce or subsequent to a prior modification.”}

Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.raw_text: Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 186 (2016)
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have held that when post‑judgment circumstances affecting a child’s daily life and stability significantly change, and the existing order is no longer consistent with the child’s best interests, a Probate and Family Court may and should modify the order.
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.case_name: N-Tek Construction Services, Inc. v. Hartford Fire Insurance Co.
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns notice requirements under G. L. c. 149, § 29 for bond claims on a public construction project; it does not involve family law, child custody, or post‑judgment modification standards. Nothing in the case addresses changes in a child’s circumstances, best interests analysis, or the authority of the Probate and Family Court to modify prior orders. Accordingly, it does not support the stated proposition about modification of child-related orders in Massachusetts Probate and Family Court.
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: Section 29, which has long-standing antecedents, is a remedial law intended to protect laborers and material suppliers from nonpayment by contractors and subcontractors involved in the construction or repair of public buildings and public works... A person who has furnished labor or materials for public works and who has not been fully paid has a right under § 29 to seek recovery under the bond of the general contractor in satisfaction of amounts justly due.

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have held that when post‑judgment circumstances affecting a child’s daily life and stability significantly change, and the existing order is no longer consistent with the child’s best interests, a Probate and Family Court may and should modify the order.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal and child-support modification case, not a general custody‑modification decision based on post‑judgment changes in a child’s daily life and stability. The court affirms dismissal of the mother’s complaint for modification seeking removal, applying the Yannas ‘real advantage/best interests’ test under G.L. c. 208, § 30. Nowhere does the court articulate a general rule that when post‑judgment circumstances significantly change and the existing order is no longer consistent with the child’s best interests, the Probate and Family Court may and should modify the order; nor does it modify custody or visitation on that basis. The case therefore does not support the broad proposition stated.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.relevant_excerpt: “The mother, Dawn Michelle Murray, appeals from a judgment of the Probate and Family Court dismissing her complaint for modification, which sought to remove the minor children of the marriage to the State of California. Where the parent seeking to move has primary physical custody of the children, the standard governing removal of the minor children from the Commonwealth requires a determination whether there is a real advantage to the custodial parent and consideration of the best interests of the children and the interests of both parents.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have held that when post‑judgment circumstances affecting a child’s daily life and stability significantly change, and the existing order is no longer consistent with the child’s best interests, a Probate and Family Court may and should modify the order.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion is a direct appeal from an original divorce judgment addressing initial custody, visitation, and property division. It does not involve a post‑judgment modification request, changed circumstances after entry of a prior order, or the standard for when a Probate and Family Court may modify an existing custody or parenting order. The case instead discusses best‑interests analysis in an original custody determination, so it does not provide authority for the proposition about modifying orders based on post‑judgment changes in a child’s circumstances.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the children in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future, and it is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.”

Blake v. Blake, 413 Mass. 823 (1992).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have held that when post‑judgment circumstances affecting a child’s daily life and stability significantly change, and the existing order is no longer consistent with the child’s best interests, a Probate and Family Court may and should modify the order.
Blake v. Blake, 413 Mass. 823 (1992).support_reasoning: The opinion in Blake v. Blake is a criminal case involving drug trafficking, focused on issues of search warrants, probable cause, Franks hearings, and securing premises. It does not involve Probate and Family Court, child custody, post‑judgment circumstances, or best‑interests standards for children. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition about modification of family court orders based on changed circumstances affecting a child’s daily life and stability.
Blake v. Blake, 413 Mass. 823 (1992).relevant_excerpt: Securing a dwelling, on the basis of probable cause, to prevent the destruction or removal of evidence while a search warrant is being sought is not itself an unreasonable seizure of the dwelling or its contents. Segura v. United States, 468 U.S. 796, 810 (1984). Police officers may secure an area to be searched before a warrant is procured as long as the search does not commence before issuance of the warrant. Commonwealth v. Yesilciman, 406 Mass. 736, 743 (1990), and cases cited.
